questions.question:
Question 1: You are conducting a cohort study in a group of headload workers to identify the risk factors 
for developing low back pain in future. This type of study falls under which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Cohort studies fall under non-experimental (observational) analytical studies. Classification of epidemiological studies: • Observational studies: allow nature to take its own course, the investigator measures but does 
not intervene. It is further classified into: • Descriptive studies: limited to describing the occurrence of a disease in a population. • Analytical studies: go further by analyzing the relationship between health status and other 
variables. It includes: • Ecological studies • Cross-sectional studies • Case-control studies • Cohort studies • Experimental studies or interventional studies: it involves an active attempt to change a disease 
determinant or the progress of a disease, and is similar in design to experiments in other sciences. • Randomized controlled trials • Field trials • Community trials

questions.question:
Question 3: Identify the type of study from the following design: 92 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The design given is of a case-control study. It proceeds from effect to cause and is done after the 
exposure and outcome have occurred. It tries to determine the possible exposure factors after a known disease incidence. This is the first 
approach to test causal hypotheses and uses controls to support or refute an inference. Retrospective or historical cohort study, on the other hand, tries to compare the risk of developing 
a disease to some already known exposure factors. Ex: risk of lung cancer in uranium miners, risk 
of angiosarcoma in persons exposed to polyvinyl chloride etc. Retrospective cohort studies are more economical and quicker than prospective cohort studies.

questions.question:
Question 4: A study was conducted among a group of 500 patients with lung cancer and another group of 
300 people chosen from the general population. Both the groups were questioned about their 
exposure to smoking. What kind of study is this?
questions.explanation:
This is a case-control study. In this scenario, 500 patients constitute the cases and 300 
people from the general population constitute the controls. The study is done from effect (lung 
cancer) to cause (smoking).

questions.question:
Question 5: A case-control study was conducted to evaluate the association between lifestyle risk factors 
and the prevalence of dyslipidemia. Which of the following is not an advantage of this type of 
study?
questions.explanation:
Incidence cannot be calculated from case-control studies. Incidence can be calculated from cohort 
studies, also known as longitudinal studies.

questions.question:
Question 6: A case-control study was conducted to see if symptoms of upper gastrointestinal dysfunction 
occurred more frequently in patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Which of the 
following cannot be used as controls in this study?
questions.explanation:
Siblings cannot be used as controls while studying genetic conditions because the outcome would 
be distorted due to their similarities. Controls in a case-control study: • Usually disease-free • Can be up to 4 times the number of cases in small studies • In large studies, a 1:1 ratio of cases and controls can be sought • Sources: general population, hospitals, relatives (spouses and siblings), neighbors, or colleagues • Although, siblings cannot be used as controls for studies on genetic conditions 103 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following is not a cause of bias in a case-control study?
questions.explanation:
Hawthorne bias is not seen in case-control studies. This bias occurs when the subjects change 
their attitude/ actions while under observation. This distorts the results of the cohort or 
experimental studies. The bias that are seen in the case-control study are: • Confounding • Recall bias • Selection bias • Berkesonian bias • Interviewer's bias

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following is not true about random errors?

options.d: Systematic errors are different from random errors

questions.explanation:
Random errors are not causes of bias. Random error arises when a value of the sample measurement diverges, due to chance alone, 
from that of the true population value. They can never be completely eliminated. Sources of random errors are individual biological variations, sampling errors, and measurement 
errors. Systematic errors are also called biases. They are different from random errors.

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following factors in a study will cause Berkesonian bias?

options.a: Interviewer asking leading questions to the subjects
options.b: Different rates of hospital admission of different diseases
options.c: Researcher's belief in the treatment changing the outcome of the study
options.d: Cases that are lost to follow-up

questions.explanation:
Berkesonian bias occurs due to the different rates of hospital admission of people with different 
diseases. It is a type of selection bias termed after Joseph Berkeson who described it.

questions.question:
Question 10: An epidemiologist plans to conduct a prospective study instead of a retrospective study. 
Which of the following disadvantages does he aim to eliminate by conducting this study?
questions.explanation:
Recall bias can be eliminated in a prospective study. Recall bias is also called memory bias. It is widely seen in retrospective (case-control) studies as 
extensive history is taken from the participants.

questions.question:
Question 11: A study conducted in a group revealed that consumption of alcohol increases the risk of 
esophageal cancer, but it may be actually due to cigarette smoking. This happens due to:
questions.explanation:
104 
Sold by @itachibot In this scenario, cigarette smoking is related to both the outcome of esophageal cancer and 
consumption of alcohol. Thus, this is an example of a confounding factor. A confounding factor is defined as one which is associated with both exposure and outcome and is 
distributed unequally in study and control groups. In this study to determine the role of alcohol in 
the etiology of esophageal cancer, smoking is considered as a confounding factor because: • It is associated with the consumption of alcohol (exposure). • It is an independent risk factor for oesophageal cancer (outcome). In these conditions, the effects of alcohol consumption can be determined only if the influence of 
smoking is neutralized by matching.

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following is false regarding confounding factor?

options.a: It can be reduced by matching
options.b: It is associated individually with both cause and effect
options.c: It is distributed equally in both study and control groups
options.d: It is associated with the exposure of the study

questions.explanation:
A confounding factor is a factor that is associated with both exposure and diseases and is 
distributed unequally in study and control groups. It can be reduced by matching. For example, if the study is that a sedentary lifestyle can lead to coronary artery diseases, then age 
can act as a confounding factor as it is individually linked to both sedentary lifestyle and coronary 
artery diseases.

questions.question:
Question 13: A researcher is planning to conduct a study to investigate the relationship between oral 
contraceptives and breast cancer. He wants to remove age as a confounding factor. Which of 
the following methods will not help him reduce this bias?
questions.explanation:
Deletion is not a method to reduce confounding. Methods to reduce confounding are: • At the time of designing the study: • Randomization • Matching • Restriction • At the time of analysis: • Stratification • Statistical modelings like regression analysis, multivariate analysis, and the 
Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel method.

questions.question: Question 14: Matching is done for which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Matching helps only in removing the known confounding factors. Matching is the process by which controls are selected in a way that they are similar to cases in 
certain pertinent variables (e.g., age) that are known to influence the outcome of the disease. If 
not adequately matched for comparability, these variables could confound the results. 105 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 15: Which among the following is not a type of matching?
questions.explanation:
There is no type of matching called collective matching. Types of matching: • Group matching: It is also called frequency matching. It is done when a large stratum is used for 
study and a 1:1 ratio of cases and controls can be achieved. • Individual matching: It is also called matching by pairs. It can be done when the study is small 
and more controls can be selected for one case.

questions.question:
Question 16: An epidemiologist determines to evaluate the strength of association between asbestos 
exposure and mesothelioma in a case-control study. Which of the following variables would 
he use for it?
questions.explanation:
Odds ratio (OR), also known as cross-product ratio, is used to measure the strength of association 
between risk factor (asbestos exposure) and outcome (mesothelioma) in case-control studies. A case-control study yields only odds ratio and not incidence or relative risk.

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following statements is false about the odds ratio?

options.b: It is obtained from case-control studies
options.d: It is a measure of strength of association

questions.explanation:
An odds ratio (OR) of 1 indicates that there is no association or that the event is likely in both the 
groups.

questions.question:
Question 19: A research scholar is preparing to do a prospective cohort study in a hospital to evaluate the 
association of H. pylori with inflammatory bowel disease. Which of the following measures 
must she take, before starting the study?

options.a: Enrol all patients taking proton pump inhibitors
options.b: Enrol all patients on whom endoscopy was done
options.c: Exclude all patients diagnosed with inflammatory bowel disease
options.d: Exclude all patients with positive urea breath test for H. pylori

questions.explanation:
All patients diagnosed with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) must be excluded from a 
prospective cohort study, as the study progresses from cause to effect. The study begins before the 
disease under study has occurred.

questions.question: Question 20: Which of the following is not true about cohort study?

options.b: It is always a prospective study design
options.d: Outcome is not present at the start of study

questions.explanation:
Although cohort studies are called prospective studies, there are subtypes of cohort studies that do 
not follow the prospective study design like historical (retrospective) cohort studies. Framingham Heart Study is one of the most famous long-term cardiovascular prospective cohort 
studies.

questions.question: Question 21: Hawthorne effect is seen in which of the following studies?
questions.explanation:
Hawthorne effect is seen in cohort studies. It refers to the phenomenon when study subjects 
change or alter their behaviour during the course of the study, which results in different outcomes 
and underestimation of risks.

questions.question: Question 22: What is the ratio of the incidence of the disease in the exposed to that of the non-exposed?
questions.explanation:
The ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is 
called relative risk (RR).

questions.question:
Question 23: Calculate the risk ratio when the incidence of the disease in exposed is 30 and that in 
non-exposed is 5.
questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, risk ratio or relative risk (RR) is 6. Here, the incidence of disease in the exposed is 30 and that in the non-exposed is 5. Thus, RR = 30/5 = 6. 107 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 24: A cohort study was conducted among 10,000 smokers and 10,000 non-smokers. They were 
followed up over a period of 20 years. It was found that 100 of the smokers and 10 of the 
non-smokers developed oral squamous cell carcinoma. Calculate the relative risk.
questions.explanation:
The relative risk in the given scenario is 10. Here, the incidence in exposed is 0.01 (100/10000). Incidence in non-exposed is 0.001 
(10/10000). Relative Risk = Incidence in exposed/ Incidence in non-exposed = 0.01/0.001 = 10.

questions.question:
Question 26: 98 
Sold by @itachibot The difference between the incidence of disease among exposed and incidence among non 
exposed is given by which of the following variables?
questions.explanation:
The difference between the incidence of disease among exposed and incidence among 
non-exposed is given by attributable risk. Attributable risk is often expressed as a percentage. 108 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 27: A study conducted among smokers shows that 80% of the cases of lung cancer are due to 
cigarette smoking. Which of the following variables indicates this?
questions.explanation:
Attributable risk indicates to what extent the disease under study can be attributed to the 
exposure. Here, cigarette smoking is attributed to be the cause of 80% of lung cancers in smokers.

questions.question:
Question 28: A study found that the incidence of bladder carcinoma is 5 times higher in smokers than in 
non smokers. Calculate the attributable risk.
questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, the attributable risk (AR) is 80%. Taking the incidence of disease in non-exposed as x, the incidence of disease in exposed would be 
5x. 109 
Sold by @itachibot Attributable risk (AR) would be given as [(5x - x)/5x] x 100 = 80%.

questions.question:
Question 29: In a population of ˜000 people, 2100 are alcoholics. 70 alcoholics and 23 non-alcoholics 
developed cirrhosis. What is the attributable risk?
questions.explanation: In the given scenario, the attributable risk (AR) is ˜0%. Number of people exposed (to alcohol) = 2100 Number of people not exposed (to alcohol) = 6˜00 Incidence of cirrhosis among exposed = 70/2100 (IExposed) Incidence of cirrhosis among non-exposed = 23/6˜00 (INon-exposed) Attributable risk (AR) = [ ( IExposed - INon-exposed) / IExposed ]*100 = [ (70/2100 - 23/6˜00) / (70/2100)] *100 = [ ˜ / 10 ] *100 = ˜0 Thus, the attributable risk (AR) is ˜0%.

questions.question: Question 30: Which of the following is the numerator in the formula for population-attributable risk?

options.a: Incidence among exposed minus incidence among non-exposed
options.b: Incidence among non-exposed minus incidence among exposed
options.c: Incidence in the total population minus incidence among non-exposed
options.d: Incidence in the total population minus incidence among exposed

questions.explanation:
Incidence in the total population minus incidence among non-exposed is the numerator in 
population-attributable risk (PAR). Population attributable risk is obtained from cohort studies. It provides an estimate of the amount 
by which the disease could be reduced in that population if the suspected factor was eliminated or 
modified. 110 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 31: A study was done in the Indian population to correlate the deaths due to myocardial 
infarction and dietary practices. What is this type of study known as?
questions.explanation:
This is an example of an ecological study. As the study was done in the Indian population, it can 
be inferred that population was taken as the unit of the study. The study was done to correlate the deaths and dietary practices, and hence ecological studies are 
also called correlational studies.

questions.question: Question 32: Which among the following is the weakest study design to prove causation?
questions.explanation:
Ecological studies take a population as a unit. They provide the weakest evidence for causality 
because of extrapolation to individuals from regional data. Randomized control trials (RCTs) provide the strongest design amongst the options given. 
Case-control and cohort studies have moderate ability to provide evidence for causality.

questions.question:
Question 33: What kind of bias is implied by assigning group characteristics to people which they may not 
possess as individuals?

options.a: Study and control groups are blinded
options.c: The sample size required depends upon the hypothesis
options.d: The dropouts from the trial are not included in the analysis

questions.explanation:
An ecological fallacy results when characteristics of the group are assigned inappropriately to 
individuals. 111 
Sold by @itachibot Experimental Epidemiology
